However, someone disqualified due to a Torah transgression is ineligible to act as a messenger for a get, as they are not trusted to say "it was written in my presence and signed in my presence." But if they have a written authorization in their hand, they are also eligible, as we do not rely on their trustworthiness. This is explained in Siman 141. Furthermore, even women who are not trusted to say "her husband died" are trusted to bring her get. What is the difference between a get and a death? It is because the document itself provides evidence (Gittin 23).

2 And these are the invalid ones: a deaf-mute, an imbecile, a minor, a Samaritan, and a servant, for all of these are invalid for any agency. In Siman 141, it is explained that there are those who validate a servant, see there. Also, a blind person is invalid because he needs to say "in my presence it was written and in my presence it was signed," and he cannot see the writing and the signing. See what is written in Siman 142 that there is another reason to invalidate a blind person, for the agent needs to recognize the man and the woman, and the blind person is unable to recognize.

3 The rabbi should inform the agent that he will be prohibited from marrying this divorced woman. If he does not inform him, the agent may later contest and say, "Had I known this, I would not have agreed to be the agent." The rabbi should warn him to take a distinct identifying mark on the get (divorce document) so that if it perhaps leaves his possession, he can recognize it. He should be careful to keep the get in his possession as much as possible until he delivers it to the woman. However, if it happens to leave his possession, he should have a distinct identifying mark. Our custom is to make distinct identifying marks, and at the time of receiving the get, we ask the agent, and he states the identifying marks. This is a good custom and should not be changed.

In the case of a get (divorce document) delivered by a messenger, the husband must prepare four witnesses: two for the get and two for the authorization. The witnesses for the get cannot serve as witnesses for the authorization, since they testify about the get witnesses. The witnesses for the authorization must also observe all matters related to the get, which includes the annulment of any coercion, the instruction to write and sign it for its specific purpose, and they must see that it is written and signed for its specific purpose. The main requirement is that they witness the appointment of the messenger and how the husband appoints the messenger. This is the essence of the authorization.

The appointment of the agent is first of all, before anything else, before he nullifies declarations, and certainly before the writing. The husband, the agent, the scribe, and all the witnesses stand before the rabbi, and the rabbi asks the agent if he willingly accepts the agency, and perhaps he is coerced into this. The agent responds, "I willingly accept to be an agent and I am not coerced in this." And if he is a paid agent, the husband makes the transaction with him beforehand, and then he accepts with a symbolic act of acquisition on the agency, because some say that an act of acquisition is required on the agency. And so wrote the Rambam in Chapter 5 of Hilchot Mechirah that this is the custom.

The husband then says to the agent in the presence of all the witnesses: "Behold, I hereby appoint you, [name of the agent], to be my agent to deliver a get (bill of divorce) to my wife, [name of the wife]. You, or your agent, or the agent of your agent, even up to a hundred agents, and even without any compulsion. I give you, and your agent, and the agent of your agent, even up to a hundred agents, permission to deliver the get into her hand wherever you find her. Your hand shall be like my hand, your action like my action, your speech like my speech, and your delivery like my delivery. As soon as the get reaches her hand, whether from your hand, or the hand of your agent, or the hand of the agent of your agent, even up to a hundred agents, she shall be divorced from me and permitted to any man. I accept upon myself, with all the stringency and oath of the Torah, that I will not nullify either the get or the agency." And the agent responds: "Thus I will do."

7 Afterwards, the rabbi begins arranging the get (divorce document) like any other get, asking the husband if he is giving the get willingly and nullifying any pre-existing declarations. The scribe gives him the paper and ink, etc., and he gives all of this to the scribe and commands him to write it for his sake and for her sake, and the witnesses to sign for his sake and for her sake, all as explained in the previous arrangement. Only in the nullification of declarations, he will add the agency, meaning that he nullifies all the words he spoke about the get and about the agency. The rabbi will caution the agent to listen to all of this, and the main thing in the writing is for his sake and for her sake. The scribe writes the get and does not mention the place where the woman is standing today, etc., because she is not here. Also, where he is currently cannot be written because the agent might find her in another place. The witnesses sign, and the agent stands by the witnesses' signatures, observing from beginning to end. During the writing of the get, it is not necessary to stand except until the scribe writes the name of the man, the woman, and the date, and no more. He should listen carefully as the scribe says he is writing for her sake, and as the witnesses say they are signing for her sake. Also, the authorization witnesses will see the writing and the signatures, even though their main testimony is about the agency.

8 After the writing and signing and reading of the get (divorce document) and the rabbi's questions to the scribe and the witnesses as with any get, and after the nullification of the declarations once again regarding the get and the agency as in the first instance before the writing, the agent should stand in place of the woman opposite the husband, with the witnesses of the delivery standing by his side. The agent should remove any rings and anything that could be a barrier from his hands, and bring his hands together as the woman does when receiving the get. The husband holds the get above his hands and says to him in the presence of the witnesses, "You, so-and-so son of so-and-so, take this get to my wife, so-and-so daughter of so-and-so, and place this get in her hand wherever you find her. Your hand will be as my hand, your action as my action, your mouth as my mouth, and your speech as my speech, and your giving as my giving. I give you permission to appoint an agent and that agent to appoint another agent, even up to a hundred agents, without any coercion until this get reaches her hand. Immediately when this get reaches her hand from your hand or from the hand of your agent or from the hand of the agent of your agent, even up to a hundred agents, she will be divorced by it from me and permitted to any man." Immediately, the get is handed to the agent, and the agent receives it.

After the agent receives the get (divorce document), the rabbi takes the get from him and reads it again with the witnessing witnesses and asks the questions again to the scribe and the witnesses. He folds the get and returns it to the agent, instructing him to keep it properly so that it does not get damaged and does not leave his possession. He makes distinct signs on it, like holes on the sides of certain letters, and afterwards, they write the authorization. They must be careful not to write the authorization before the completion of the get, since in the authorization it is written "in our presence, the husband delivered the get."
And this is the text of the authorization:

In our presence, the undersigned below, on such-and-such Shabbat, on such-and-such day of the month of such-and-such year since the creation of the world, according to the reckoning we count here in such-and-such city situated on such-and-such river and on such-and-such springs, so-and-so the son of so-and-so delivered a bill of divorce into the hands of so-and-so the son of so-and-so to take it to his wife, so-and-so the daughter of so-and-so, to give it into her hand. And thus spoke before us the husband so-and-so the son of so-and-so to his emissary, so-and-so, take this bill of divorce to my wife, so-and-so the daughter of so-and-so, and place it into her hand wherever you find her. And your hand shall be as my hand, and your action as my action, and your mouth as my mouth, and your speech as my speech, and your giving as my giving. And I give you permission to appoint an emissary in your place, and an emissary of an emissary, and another emissary of an emissary, even up to one hundred emissaries, and even without any duress, until this bill of divorce reaches her hand. And as soon as this bill of divorce reaches my wife's hand, mentioned above, from your hand or from your emissary's hand or from the hand of your emissary's emissary up to one hundred emissaries, she will be divorced from me and permitted to any man. And the bill of divorce that was made upon it, so-and-so the emissary to take it as written above, was written and signed in such-and-such city situated on such-and-such river, etc., on such-and-such Shabbat, on such-and-such day of the month of such-and-such year since the creation of the world, and its witnesses signed upon it, so-and-so and so-and-so. And in our presence, the husband so-and-so nullified all notifications he made regarding this bill of divorce. And also in our presence, the husband so-and-so accepted upon himself with all stringency and the oath of the Torah not to nullify the bill of divorce or the emissary. And what we saw and was done in our presence, we wrote and signed, and everything is valid and established.
Statement of [Name], son of [Name], witness
"The statement of [so-and-so], son of [so-and-so], the witness"
And the Beit Din (rabbinical court) certifies this, and this is its formulation.

In a session of three, we functioned as one court, and two witnesses signed in our presence: so-and-so, the son of so-and-so, and so-and-so, the son of so-and-so, and we affirmed and validated it as required.

The passage provided, "נאום פב"פ דיין," roughly translates to:

"Speech/statement by the judge PBP"

(Note: "פב"פ" could be an acronym for a name or title of the judge, which might need further context for an exact translation.)
The translation of the passage: Speech of so-and-so, the judge
Speech of P.B.P., Judge
The judges need to see that when the witnesses sign the authorization, they ensure that the authorization is written well and does not contain any erasures or interpolations.

And if there are conditions, they should be fulfilled before the signatures, and it should be ensured that each letter is written separately so that the reader can easily understand it. And know that one of the great scholars of our time has pointed out to us a significant omission in the authorization document, which the great authorities did not notice. This is because it is explained in Choshen Mishpat, Siman 39, that any document made without the instruction of the interested party does not have the status of a document. It is not clarified in the authorization document that the principal instructed the witnesses to write the authorization. Therefore, he acted in the case of a power of attorney for a Get (divorce document) in my place and added to the authorization that the principal instructed them to write the authorization. I responded to him that our predecessors did well not to mention this because the rule that a document made without the instruction of the interested party is not a document applies specifically to a document that involves some obligation to another in its writing. By law, it is not possible to do this, such as a borrower who borrows from a lender orally; it is forbidden for them to create a document, as this would change from an oral loan to a written loan, and he would not be believed to say he repaid, and it would be collectible from purchasers, as explained by the Rashbam in Bava Batra 40, s.v. "Hoda'ah," and Tosafot there, s.v. "Mach'ah." Therefore, Tosafot there and in Ketubot 20, labored to explain.

Why did the Sages permit, in the case of a declaration of protest, to write without command and without the knowledge of the one obligated? But in the authorization of a divorce document, the obligation is upon the woman, and indeed, in a divorce, her consent is not required. For the husband, it is not an obligation since it is his will, and on the contrary, it is to his benefit, as through this, the divorce document will reach her as per his will, since he is divorcing willingly. Therefore, the husband's consent and command are not needed here (see what is written in Aruch HaShulchan there, section 18).

The passage you have provided appears to be a single word, "סליק," which means "completed," "finished," or "ascended." 

So the translation is:
"Completed"
Order of the Get from the Messenger to the Woman

The messenger, when he brings the get (divorce document), must deliver it in the presence of three people who constitute a Beit Din (rabbinic court). This serves as the validation, and the validation of documents requires three people. According to the fundamental law, the messenger can be counted among the three, as a messenger can serve as a witness, and a witness can serve as a judge in rabbinic law. This validation is of rabbinic origin (Gittin 5b). However, if the witness is unfit to serve as a judge, such as a woman or a relative, then three people are needed excluding the unfit witness. Therefore, we are stringent in all cases to ensure that there are three people. Additionally, we are stringent that besides the three who constitute the Beit Din, there should be another two as witnesses to the delivery. This is explained at length in Siman 142, see there.

Therefore, the rabbi in place of the woman appoints two additional judges to sit with him, and two other men stand before them as witnesses of the delivery, with the messenger and the woman standing before the rabbi.

The rabbi asks the messenger, "What do you want?" The messenger responds, "I am the agent of so-and-so, son of so-and-so, to deliver a get (divorce document) to his wife, so-and-so, daughter of so-and-so, and she is the woman standing before you." The rabbi asks him, "Do you recognize her as his wife?" He replies, "I recognize her." (And if he truly does not recognize her, witnesses will testify before him that she is the wife of so-and-so.) The rabbi then asks the messenger, "Perhaps the husband set a specific time for the divorce or gave you some condition?" The messenger responds, "He did not set a time for me nor did he make any condition." Afterwards, the rabbi asks the woman if she is willing to accept the get, and she says, "Yes."

Section 4: And they take the authorization from the agent and read it to ensure it is properly written and correctly validated. It is good if they recognize at least one of the judges' signatures, but after the fact, it does not invalidate it, as our teacher the Rema wrote at the end of section 142. And it is obvious that when the agent says "in my presence it was written and in my presence it was signed," there is no need at all for the authorization, and it is merely an enhancement.

After they have read the authorization document, they ask the agent if the husband was healthy at the time the get (divorce document) was given to him or if perhaps the agent heard that the husband had died or that he had annulled the get or the agency. The agent responds: "He was healthy and I have not heard anything about its annulment." They also ask the wife if she heard that the husband had died or any form of annulment, and she responds similarly: "I have not heard anything." Afterward, they return to the agent and ask if he himself annulled his agency or appointed another agent in his place or if he is compelled (under duress) regarding the agency. He responds: "I did not annul my agency, nor did I appoint another agent in my place, and I am not under duress regarding the agency." They also ask him if he perhaps made a declaration of protest regarding the agency, and he replies: "No."

The rabbi takes the get (divorce document) from his hand and reads it along with the witnesses of the delivery. After reading it, the rabbi asks the agent if he saw that the husband gave the paper, the ink, the quill, and all the writing instruments to the scribe. [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Did you hear the husband instruct the scribe to write it for his sake, her sake, and for the sake of the divorce? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Did you hear the scribe write it for his sake, her sake, and for the sake of the divorce? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Did you hear the witnesses sign it for his sake, her sake, and for the sake of the divorce? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Were you present when the scribe wrote his name, her name, and the date? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Were you present when the witnesses signed? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Did you see that the witnesses were together and signed in each other's presence? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Was the get dry when the husband handed it to you? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Do you recognize the get as the one the husband gave you? [The agent answers:] I recognize it well. [The rabbi asks:] Do you have identifying marks on it? [The agent answers:] Yes. [The rabbi asks:] Tell us the identifying marks. The agent answers: I have a clear identifying mark, such as [description], or two marks, or more, all depending on what was done. The court observes that this is indeed the case.

Immediately, the get (bill of divorce) is folded, and the emissary and the woman stand before the rabbi, with the emissary facing the woman. The witnesses to the delivery stand on either side. The rabbi instructs the woman to remove the rings from her fingers and any other object that may be an interposition. He informs her that upon receiving this get, she will be separated from her husband. He instructs her to place her hands together, with her palms touching from below and her fingers apart from above. The emissary holds the get above her hands and says to her (in Hebrew, explaining his words in the local language):

8 This is your get (divorce document) that your husband, so-and-so the son of so-and-so, sent to you, and behold, you are hereby divorced by it from him (the letter nun should be emphasized), and you are permitted to marry any man. This get was written and signed in my presence. Immediately, he gives the get into her hand, and she takes it into her hands, lifts it up high, and tucks it under the garment on her heart. She then walks around the house back and forth no less than four cubits, and then she returns and gives the get to the rabbi. The rabbi, together with the witnesses, reads it and asks the messenger some of the aforementioned questions, although this is not essential. The get is torn both lengthwise and widthwise, and they inform her of Rabbeinu Tam's enactment to prevent slander. They also inform the woman that she should not remarry until 92 days have passed and that she should not marry a kohen (priest).
This passage seems to contain only the word "סליק" which is often used in rabbinic literature to signify the conclusion of a section or topic, roughly translating to "end" or "concluded."

Even in the case of a divorce document (get) for a betrothed woman, the agent should tell her, "This is your get that your husband has sent you." Similarly, in a power of attorney, the husband's name is written because even a betrothed man is called a husband. However, in the questions that the rabbi asks the agent, the term "betrothed" is mentioned, such as when asking if this is the get that so-and-so, the betrothed man, sent, and similar questions, in order to clarify the matter as precisely as possible. According to the law, there is no strict requirement in this regard.

In the case of a get (divorce document) involving a completely wicked person, where there is concern that he might not heed the oath he swore not to nullify the get or the agency, our ancient sages devised a good remedy. Initially, the get should be handed over to the agent in the form of an agency for acceptance, and even though the wife did not appoint him as an agent for acceptance, we testify that it is a benefit for her. Afterwards, the get should be given to him in the form of an agency for delivery. Thus, even if G-d forbid he nullifies it, we can rely in a pressing situation that she is already divorced based on the acceptance. We have explained this in Siman 141, Se'if 157, see there.

11 You should know that in the matter of an agent for acceptance (of a get, Jewish bill of divorce), we do not practice this nowadays, except in pressing circumstances where an agent for acceptance is appointed. The Shulchan Aruch does not clarify the procedure for this, but we have explained the entire process with divine assistance in section 141 from paragraph 85 to paragraph 91, and some of this is also in section 140, paragraph 4. Therefore, in situations where it is necessary to appoint an agent for acceptance, they should proceed as we have explained there, with God's help.
The order of a get (divorce document) sent by mail (post).

**Section 1:** We have already elaborated in Siman 141 from paragraph 50 to paragraph 65 that it is completely permissible to send a get (Jewish bill of divorce) via the postal service. This was also the practice in the generation before us, due to the fact that Jews are scattered and separated from one end of the world to the other, making it impossible to send an emissary to distant lands. Therefore, the great sages of the previous generation permitted this. Additionally, we explained there in paragraph 63 that there was someone who wanted to institute that the husband should appoint an emissary here like all other emissaries, and that emissary should appoint another emissary in the place where the wife is, without the husband's presence. We wrote there in paragraph 64 that it is absolutely forbidden to do so, and in my humble opinion, there is a severe prohibition in this matter. We elaborated there on the reasoning behind this, and therefore, we will explain the procedure here with God's help.

Initially, there should be an exchange of letters between the rabbi in the place of the man and the rabbi in the place of the woman. This is beneficial so that the rabbi in the place of the woman can recognize the handwriting of the rabbi in the place of the man, and the authorization will be valid according to the law through the recognition of the signatures. When the rabbi in the place of the man writes to the rabbi in the place of the woman that the husband agrees to the divorce, and the rabbi in the place of the woman responds that the wife also agrees to receive the divorce, the rabbi in the place of the man will write the name of the man in his location, stating that this man agrees to be his agent to deliver the get (divorce document) to his wife. He will also write the name of the man and his father's name according to the proper format.

The rabbi, when arranging the get, should appoint four witnesses: two for the get and two for the authorization. Before arranging the get, the husband should declare in front of the witnesses: "I hereby appoint so-and-so, who is in such-and-such a place, as an agent to deliver a get to my wife, so-and-so, wherever he may find her. His hand shall be as my hand, etc., according to the formula specified in the get by an agent." He should also swear not to nullify the get or the agency.

Afterwards, the rabbi arranges the get (bill of divorce) like all other gets, and after completing it, the husband says: "I hereby appoint so-and-so who is in such-and-such place as my agent to deliver this get to my wife so-and-so, and he shall place this get in her hand wherever he finds her, and his hand shall be like my hand, etc. And immediately upon this get reaching her hand from the agent so-and-so or from the agent of the agent, she shall be divorced by it from me and permitted to any man." And he holds the get in his hand while saying this. Afterwards, the authorization is written in this form, and the authorization is not written before the completion, as mentioned in the previous get.

5 Before us, undersigned below, on Shabbat, on such and such a date of the month of such and such, in the year such and such since the creation of the world, according to the counting that we count here in such and such city situated by such and such river and by the waters of such and such spring, so-and-so son of so-and-so appointed so-and-so son of so-and-so in such and such place to deliver this Get (divorce document) to his wife so-and-so daughter of so-and-so. And thus said before us the husband, so-and-so son of so-and-so: "Behold, I appoint so-and-so son of so-and-so in such and such place as an agent to deliver this Get to my wife so-and-so daughter of so-and-so, and he shall deliver this Get into her hand wherever he shall find her, and his hand shall be as my hand, etc. And as soon as this Get reaches her hand from my agent or from the agent of my agent, she shall be divorced from me and permitted to any man." And the Get which was made upon it, so-and-so from such and such place as an agent to deliver it to the above-mentioned woman, was written and signed in such and such city situated by etc., on Shabbat, on such and such a date of the month of such and such, in the year such and such since the creation of the world, and its witnesses signed therein were so-and-so and so-and-so. And before us, he nullified it, etc., etc., according to the form of authorization explained above with the confirmation of the Bet Din as mentioned above.

6 Afterwards, they should place the get (bill of divorce) and the authorization closed in a box and put identifying marks on the get. It is appropriate that the husband himself should place them in the post office and inform the rabbi in the wife's location in a special letter how they sent this get. It is also appropriate to send it in the name of the messenger who performed the task and to inform the rabbi in the wife's location of the signatures placed on the box. They should view this as a sign, even though it is not necessary; in any case, it is a good practice for extra caution.

When the agent who is in place of the woman receives the get (bill of divorce), he should come to the local rabbi with the woman. The rabbi will ask him: "What is your purpose?" He will respond: "So-and-so from such-and-such place appointed me as an agent in his absence to deliver this get to his wife, so-and-so, and she is the woman standing here before you. This is the get and the authorization." The rabbi will sit with two other people, and in addition to this, two witnesses will stand by to serve as witnesses to the delivery, as it is written.

The teacher takes the authorization document from his hand and reads it together with the witnesses, who should recognize the signatures of the Beit Din that validated the authorization, or at the very least recognize one signature. It is necessary to recognize the validation because the agent cannot say "in my presence it was written and in my presence it was signed," thus requiring the validation of the authorization document according to the law. Refer to what our teacher, the Rema, wrote at the end of Siman 142.

Afterwards, the rabbi takes the get (divorce document) and reads it with the witnesses. Then, he asks the agent and the woman if they have heard that the husband has died or if they have heard that the get or the agency has been annulled, and they respond "No." There is no need to question this agent further since he was not present at the time the get was written. Afterwards, the rabbi asks the woman if she accepts the get willingly, and she responds "Yes."

The emissary and the woman then stand before the rabbi, with the emissary facing the woman. The witnesses of the delivery stand on the sides. The emissary takes the get (divorce document) in his hand, and she brings her hands close together, closed at the bottom and open at the top. The emissary holds the get above her hands.

Section 11: He tells her, "This is your Get (divorce document) that your husband sent you from such and such place, and he appointed me as his agent in his place to deliver you this Get. And you are thereby divorced from him (emphasize the 'him'), and you are permitted to any man. And I am an agent of the court." He explains these matters in the vernacular language, and the Rabbi clarifies the matter to her.

She takes the get (divorce document) and lifts it up, placing it under the garment on her chest. She then walks back and forth not less than four cubits, gives the get to the rabbi, and the rabbi reads it again with the witnesses, tearing it crosswise. He mentions Rabbeinu Tam's ordinance to prevent casting aspersions and warns her not to marry before ninety-two days and that she is forbidden to a Kohen, and dismisses her in peace.

Translation:
Completed.
Order of an Agent When Appointing a Second Agent

The rabbi sits with his two associates, and two witnesses stand by. Two messengers come, and the rabbi asks, "What is your purpose?" The first one says, "I, [name], am a messenger from [name] to deliver a get (divorce document) to his wife [name], and I have the authority to appoint another messenger in my place even without compulsion, as you can see in the authorization. I wish to appoint [name], who stands before you, as the messenger in my place." The rabbi asks the second messenger, "Are you [name]? Do you wish to be the messenger to deliver the get to the woman [name]?" And he says, "Yes."

Afterwards, they take the authorization document and examine it to see if it was written properly and if it is validated, and if they recognize the handwriting of the judges from the validation. Even if they do not recognize it, it is acceptable in a pressing situation, as stated at the end of section 142. Then they read the get (divorce document) and examine if it was written according to the law, and the rabbi reads it with the witnesses.

The rabbi should ask the first agent if the husband did not set a time for him (to deliver the get), or if he did not hear that perhaps the husband had canceled the get or the agency, or perhaps the husband had died. (The agent should respond:) No. (The rabbi should then ask:) Maybe you yourself canceled your agency, or perhaps you declared a precondition (moda'ah) about the agency, or perhaps you are an agent under coercion. (The agent should respond:) No. The rabbi should then ask the second agent: Maybe you heard that the husband had died, or that he canceled the get or the agency, or are you an agent under coercion? (The agent should respond:) No.

4 The rabbi asks the first witness: Did you see the husband give the scribe paper, ink, a quill, and all the writing instruments? Yes. Did you hear him instruct the scribe to write the get (divorce document) for his name and her name and their specific purpose? Yes. Did you hear him instruct the witnesses to sign for his name and her name and their specific purpose? Yes. Did you hear from the scribe and the witnesses that they wrote and signed for his name and her name and their specific purpose? Yes. Were you present when the scribe wrote the name of the man, the woman, and the date? Yes. Were you present when the witnesses signed from beginning to end? Yes. Is this the get that the husband gave you? Yes. Do you recognize it? Yes. Do you have identifying marks on it? Yes. State the identifying marks. They are such and such. Did the witnesses sign in each other’s presence? Yes.

5. They fold the get (divorce document), and the two emissaries stand face to face before the rabbi, with the two witnesses on their sides. The first emissary holds the get above the hands of the second emissary, and the second one brings his hands close together, closed below and open above, and the first emissary says to him:

6 And you, Mr. P.B.P., the husband, Mr. P.B.P., appointed me to be a messenger to deliver a Get (bill of divorce) to his wife, Mrs. P.B.P., and gave me permission to appoint another messenger in my place, and a messenger of a messenger, even up to one hundred messengers, even without any compulsion, as stated in the authorization. And based on this power, I appoint you before the court and before these witnesses to deliver this Get to his wife, Mrs. P.B.P., and to place it in her hand wherever you find her, and your hand shall be as my hand, and your mouth as my mouth, and you have the ability to appoint a messenger in your place, and a messenger of a messenger up to ninety-nine messengers, even without any compulsion. And as soon as this Get reaches the hand of the said wife from your hand or from the hand of your messenger, she shall be divorced from her husband, Mr. P.B.P., and permitted to all men, and this Get was written and signed in my presence. And immediately he hands the Get to the second messenger, and the second messenger receives it and hands it to the Rabbi, and he returns and reads it with the witnesses, folds it, and hands it to the second messenger, and they write the authorization. And this is its formula: In the presence of three members of the court, we were assembled as one on such and such day of the week, on such and such date of the month of a certain year since the creation of the world, according to the count we count here in such and such city situated on such and such river, etc. And Mr. P.B.P. came before us with a Get sent by Mr. P.B.P. to divorce his wife, Mrs. P.B.P., and brought before us a validated authorization that the said husband made him a messenger to deliver this Get to his said wife, and it was written in the authorization that he gives him permission to appoint a messenger and a messenger of a messenger, even up to one hundred messengers, even without any compulsion. And based on this power, he appointed before us Mr. P.B.P. to be a messenger in his place, and before us, he handed him the Get, and thus Mr. P.B.P. said before us to Mr. P.B.P., "Take this Get to Mrs. P.B.P., daughter of Mr. P.B.P., the wife of Mr. P.B.P., and place it in her hand wherever you find her, and your hand shall be as my hand, and your mouth as my mouth, and you have the permission to appoint a messenger in your place, and a messenger of a messenger up to ninety-nine messengers, even without any compulsion. And as soon as this Get reaches the hand of the said wife from your hand or from the hand of your messenger, she shall be divorced from her husband, Mr. P.B.P., and permitted to all men, and this Get was written and signed in my presence." And this Get that Mr. P.B.P. was appointed as a messenger to deliver as stated above was written and signed in such and such city situated, etc., on such and such day of the week, etc. (as written in the Get), and its witnesses signed on it, Mr. P.B.P. and Mr. P.B.P. And what we saw and was done before us, we wrote and signed, and everything is valid and established, the declaration of Mr. P.B.P., judge, and the declaration of Mr. P.B.P., judge, and the declaration of Mr. P.B.P., judge. And they hand the Get and the authorization to the second messenger, and he goes and departs in peace.

This is the second messenger who, upon arriving at the woman's location, goes with her to the rabbi. The rabbi sits with his two associates, and two witnesses stand to serve as attendants. The rabbi asks, "What is your purpose?" The messenger replies, "I am [so-and-so], the appointed messenger of [so-and-so], who sent this divorce document through his agent [so-and-so], and granted him the authority to appoint a messenger in his place. He made me the messenger in his place to deliver the divorce document to the woman [so-and-so], and she is the woman standing with you here. Here is the authorization from the court as evidence to all my statements that I was appointed as a messenger in the court."

The rabbi takes the authorization from him and reads it to see that it was written correctly. He asks the agent if he perhaps heard that the husband died or revoked his agency or the get (divorce document). The agent replies, "I did not hear anything." The rabbi then asks the wife, and she also replies, "I did not hear anything." The rabbi asks the wife if she wants to accept the get, and she answers, "Yes." The rabbi takes the get from the agent's hand and reads it with the witnesses. He then asks the agent if he himself perhaps revoked his agency or if he is being coerced into the agency, and he replies, "No." The agent and the wife stand face to face near the rabbi, with the witnesses beside them. The wife brings her hands together, closed below and open above, and the agent holds the get above her hands and says to her in this manner:

9 This is your get (divorce document) that your husband sent to you by so-and-so, and he sent it through so-and-so, and gave him permission to appoint a proxy in his place, and he appointed me as the proxy in the presence of a court. Therefore, I am delivering this get to you, and you are thereby divorced by it from him (the "nun" should be pressed) and permitted to marry any man. I am a court-appointed proxy. He then places the get in her hand, lifts it up, and places it under the garment on her heart. She then walks around the house back and forth for not less than four cubits, and she gives the get to the rabbi. The rabbi reads it again with the witnesses and tears it crosswise, mentioning the enactment of Rabbeinu Tam to prevent slander. He informs her not to remarry until ninety-two days have passed and that she is prohibited from marrying a kohen forever. He then dismisses them in peace (and see in Siman 13 that it is proper to be stringent and count the three months from the time of the delivery).

When the second agent appoints a third agent, it is understood that he acts in the same manner as explained, appointing him in a court and recounting the events as they occurred. The court asks him only if he has not heard that the husband has died, if the husband has not revoked the get (divorce document), if he himself has not revoked his agency, and if he is not coerced regarding the agency. However, regarding the matter of the writing, it is impossible to ask him since he is the second agent and was not present at the time of the writing of the get. They write him an authorization in the following format: "In a session of three judges convened as one, on such and such a day, etc., so-and-so came before us with a get sent by so-and-so to divorce his wife, so-and-so, and presented before us an authorization according to the law, appointing him an agent before a court to deliver the get to so-and-so, the daughter of so-and-so, the wife of so-and-so. It is stated in the authorization that he has the authority to appoint an agent in his place. Therefore, this second agent appointed before us, the court, so-and-so as an agent, and before us delivered the get to him to bring to the aforementioned woman. And thus, so-and-so said before us to so-and-so, 'Take this get to so-and-so, the wife of so-and-so, and place it in her hand wherever you find her. Your hand shall be as my hand, and your mouth as my mouth, and you have the authority to appoint an agent and that agent to appoint another agent, even up to ninety-eight agents, even without coercion. As soon as this get reaches her hand from your hand or from the hand of your agent, she will be divorced from her husband, so-and-so, and permitted to marry any man.' The get, for which so-and-so was appointed as an agent to deliver, was written and signed in such-and-such a city, on such-and-such a day (as stated in the get), and its witnesses signed on it, so-and-so and so-and-so. What we saw and did before us, we have written and signed, and everything is firm and valid." Signed by: so-and-so, judge; so-and-so, judge; so-and-so, judge.

11. The giving to the hand of the third agent and the giving from the hand of the third agent to the woman is all as explained with the second agent, of course. And similarly, the third when making a fourth, and so on and so forth, up to one hundred.

12. It has already been explained in Siman 141 that when both the man and the woman are in the same city, it is preferable not to have the get (divorce document) delivered by an agent for delivery, so that the husband cannot claim that he gave it to the agent as a deposit and not for divorce. Therefore, when there is authorization, it is permitted even when both are in the same city, since the husband cannot claim that he gave it as a deposit, as the authorization proves that it was given for divorce.

13. If both the husband and wife are present, but the husband is in a hurry to leave and cannot wait until the get (divorce document) is written, he is also permitted to proceed. After he expresses that he is giving the get willingly and nullifies any prior declarations, he takes the paper, ink, quill, and writing instruments from the scribe, who has given them to him as a gift. He says in the presence of witnesses, "You, so-and-so, write for me a get for my wife, so-and-so, and write it for my name, her name, and for my purpose of divorce. And you, witnesses so-and-so and so-and-so, sign this get." This is similar to what was stated earlier regarding the scribe.

Additionally, there should be another person appointed as an agent, and the husband should say to him, "I hereby appoint you, so-and-so, as my agent to deliver this get to my wife, so-and-so. Give it to her wherever you find her. I grant you permission to appoint another agent and that agent to appoint another agent, etc., according to the authorization format." Therefore, two more witnesses are needed for the authorization, as per the law of a get delivered by an agent.

It is understood that in such a get, we do not write "the husband standing in such a place" because he is leaving, nor do we write "the wife standing in such a place," as he grants the agent permission to give it to her wherever she may be found. Perhaps she will leave before the get is written. They are not required to write the get immediately; they can write it the next day or whenever they choose, and they should write the date of the actual writing, not the date of the verbal instruction. See Shulchan Aruch, Even HaEzer, Section 149:30 (and in Pischei Teshuvah, Subsection 19).

It has already been explained that he can appoint an agent even not in his presence by saying, "I hereby appoint so-and-so as an agent to deliver a get to my wife, so-and-so," etc. It has also been explained that if it is necessary to mention any condition, it should not be mentioned, Heaven forbid, neither at the time of writing nor to the agent. Rather, he should request from the agent beforehand that when he needs to deliver the get, he should receive such-and-such from her and explicitly state that he is not imposing a condition and is explicitly saying that he is giving the get unconditionally. He is merely expressing his desire, and presumably, the agent will try to fulfill his desire. Refer to what was mentioned earlier in Section 147. It is advisable to avoid even this. With this, all the procedures for the get are completed with the help of Heaven.
The passage provided, "סליק," translates to "Completed" or "Concluded."
